newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan firms seek more spent nuclear fuel storage.
newsitem.headline: Japan firms seek more spent nuclear fuel storage.

text.p: Faced with a growing stockpile of spent radioactive material, two Japanese power companies said on Tuesday that they have asked local governments for permission to expand their current storage facilities.
The two companies, Kansai Electric Power Co Inc and Japan Atomic Power Co, cannot expand their spent nuclear fuel storage facilities without local government approval.
Japan Atomic Power said it has applied to the city and prefectural authorities of Tsuruga, Fukui prefecture on the Sea of Japan coast for permission to expand two storage facilities.
The company said it hoped to expand capacity at one nuclear fuel storage facility to 1,217 fuel bundles from the current 790 fuel bundles.
A fuel bundle is a collection of dozens of fuel rods.
A second facility would be boosted to hold 1,734 fuel bundles from the current 987.
It hopes to carry out the construction work between October 1998 and September 2000.
Japan Atomic's Tsuruga nuclear plant, which is suffering the most serious storage shortage among Japan's power companies, has said its existing storage facility in Tsuruga will be filled by 2002.
In a similar step, Kansai Electric has filed a request with the local authorities of Oimachi, Fukui prefecture for an expansion.
Kansai Electric's expansion plans call for boosting the capacity of two storage facilities to enable them to each hold 2,129 fuel bundles from the current 974 fuel bundles.
Construction work is due to take place between October 1999 and March 2002.
Spokesmen for both Japan Atomic and Kansai Electric said they had not yet estimated the cost of the expansion project.
The credibility of Japan's nuclear industry has been undermined by a series of accidents at nuclear power plants and other nuclear power facilities.
In March a fire and explosion at Japan's only spent nuclear fuel reprocessing plant in Tokaimura, northeast of Tokyo, exposed dozens of workers to low levels of radiation.
The accident has stalled progress at a new recycling and storage plant in northern Japan, which was due to start receiving spent nuclear fuel from June.
